An incomplete copper alloy unidentified object probably of Medieval date c.AD1200-1500. The object comprises a flat circular frame, pointed oval in section and decorated on both surfaces with a continuous row of sub-rectangular impressions forming a crenellated surface.  A flat rectangular metal strip is folded over the frame, the ends terminate in an uneven transverse break. Both sides of the strip are decorated stamped motifs forming a row of raised vertical pointed ovals flanked on each side with a raised crescent parallel to the sides of the oval. The object is worn with dark brown glossy patina remaining on some of the raised crenellations. Measurements: diameter of frame: 25.01mm: width of frame: 2.46mm; thickness of frame: 2.28mm. Width of pin: 6.21mm- 5.82mm weight: 2.93g.

A post-medieval silver sixpence of Elizabeth I (1558-1603), second issue dated to 1565 on coin. Rose initial mark. Mint of London.  Ref:  North (1991: 134) no. 1997. Obverse: Crowned bust left, rose behind. Legend: ELIZABETH.D;G;AN'.FR.ET.HI: REGINA Reverse: Square shield over long cross fourchee dividing the legend. Legend: POSVI/ DEV. AD/IVTORE/M. MEV; Measurements: diameter: 25.88; thickness: 0.54mm and weight: 2.78g.

A post medieval silver threepence of Charles II (AD 1660-1685) dating c. AD 1660-1662. Mint of London. Crown initial mark. As North (1991: 210) no. 2769. Obverse: Crowned bust left with mark of value III behind head, CAROLVS II D G M BR FR ET HI REX Reverse: Square shield on cross fleury, CHRISTO AUSPICE REGNO Measurements: Diameter: 18.79mm; thickness: 0.68mm and weight: 1.44g.

A complete silver medieval penny of Edward I (AD1272-1307). Canterbury mint. Probably Class 10cf3b dating c. 1307-1309. As North (1991) no: 1042/2. Measurements: diameter: 18.13mm; thickness: 1.01mm and weight: 1.30g.

A complete post medieval gunflint and lead pad dating c. AD 1600-1900. The flint is is rectangular in plan and is of the classic wedge shape in section. The exposed section of the flint has been worked creating three visible long sloping faces and a flat upper surface on the upper dorsal side. The ventral front edge has been worked with short, scaled semi-abrupt retouch. The flint is a black to translucent brown colour. The body of the flint is wrapped in a piece of folded lead, or "flint pad", intended to hold it in place within the jaws of a cock or hammer on a flintlock firearm. There appears to be a partial impression from the lock clamp on the upper surface of the lead. Measurements: length 33.01mm, width 24.07mm, thickness 11.81mm, weight 17.46g. Discussion: Other recorded gunflints with lead pads include BERK-736C0C; KENT-CBEAF2 and NMS-A24189 which notes that the flintlock was introduced in the middle of the 16th century and became the main regulation firearm for the British Army during the reign of William III. The knapped flint was used within the musket mechanism to produce a spark and could last between 20-25 shots before it had to be replaced.

A complete silver finger ring of probable medieval date (c.1000-1200). Description: The ring is sub-circular in plan, with the back section of the hoop being rectangular in cross-section and the front sub-circular, being formed with three twisted sub-rectangular wires which have been split from the band. At some points on the wires, possible peck marks are evident which were used to test the quality of the silver.  Measurements: diameter: 24mm; width: 3.8mm; thickness: 1.2mm; height (of bezel): 3.5mm; weight: 3.91g Discussion: Typically, silver finger rings formed of twisted wire have a very narrow back such as NCL-40E866, sometimes the join of two tapering ends such as KENT-4D4DB5, both of which are attributed to Viking production and dated c.800-1100. Those with rectangular backs such as the one recorded here are less common but include SUSS-6F8D1D, dated c.800-1100, and which references multiple gold parallels including YORYM-F67716 dated 9th-11th century.  It also references an almost identical example to the ring recorded here in the British Museums collections (1854,0820.6) which was '...found in the Lark Hill Hoard near Worcester. This hoard is dated to the 12th century by the presence of coins contained therein, but the ring is described in the British Museum's collection database as being 'a common type of Viking and late Anglo-Saxon ring'. KENT-EA1868 is the closest parallel that could be found on the database and includes the following discussion: ...the twisted hoop type of Viking origin is long-lived in Denmark, in fact into the early 12th century, while in England, a ring of plain rods with a plain section hammered square at the back was found in the Lark Hill Hoard, deposited later around 1173-1174 (F. Lindahl, 2003, Symboler I guld og sølv, Nationalmuseets fingerringe 1000-1700-årene, Copenhagen, 11-13, figs. 3 and 12).  It also refers to '...a silver-gilt ring of alternating twisted rods and finer twisted wires with a long, plain, rectangular section at the back, like the one from Old Romney, from a late 13th or early 14th-century context at Hangleton, Sussex (E.W. Holden, 1963, 'Excavations at the deserted medieval village of Hangleton, part 1', Sussex Archaeological Collections, 54-181, fig. 38, 18). The form and structure of both these rings are closely comparable with a further silver stray find from either England, or possibly the Near East, in the Haedeke Collection (H.-U. Haedeke, 2000, Schmuck aus drei Jahrtausenden, Cologne, 86, cat.no. 118)'.  It concludes: 'It would appear from the occurrences in early Medieval contexts, therefore, that such rings of multiple, twisted rods with longish arcs of square section at the back of the hoop and less 'corrugated' appearance represent a development of the Viking form and can be dated to the Romanesque period.' A date of c.1000-1200 is therefore suggested for the example recorded here.

A Post-Medieval gold half-guinea of George I (1714-1727), minted in London in 1720. As Spink no: 3635. Obverse description: Bust laureate right. Obverse inscription: GEORGIVS.D’G.M.BR.FR.ET.HIB REX.FD Reverse description: Cruciform shields of Arms of England, France, Ireland and Hanover; central cross, sceptre between each pair of shields. Reverse inscription: 20.BRVN ET.L.DVX S.R.I.ATH ET.EL.17 Measurements: diameter: 20.91mm: thickness: 0.78mm; weight: 3.95g. The coin has been slightly bent twice possibly into a love token.

A copper or copper-alloy leaf shaped razor or knife dating to the Middle Bronze Age c. 2150-1500 BC. The leaf shaped blade is lenticular in cross-section. One surface is almost flat and the other slightly convex possibly with the remains of a midrib. The tang is also lenticular in cross section with opposing convex surfaces. The surface extending from the flat side of the blade steeply convex and the opposing side extending from the midrib side is gently convex and almost flat. The tang measures12.44mm at the base of the blade tapering to a point. It thickens from 7.68mm tapering to 1.75mm at the tip. The side profile of the tang terminates in a curve with a sharply upturned tip.The object is covered in pale green corrosion, but is a bright copper underneath. Measurements: length: 91.86mm; width: 32.78mm; thickness of blade: 7.31mm and weight: 51.75g. Discussion: The upturned tang would have held the original wood, bone or antler handle in place. Other similar examples on the database include: LANCUM-0FBC03; LEIC-081BB1; SF5067. See also Watson, P. 1993 no. 76, a razor metal detected in 1986 in Bewdley Worcestershire and now in Birmingham museum (1987.A218.). Elle De Spretter notes that the shape is consistent with Peggy Piggot's Class I, Butler and Smith Class Ib and Jockenhovel's double edge with long oval blade and tang. References: Butler and Smith, 1956. Razors, urns and the British Middle Bronze Age', Univ London Inst Archaeol Ann Rep Vol. 12. Piggott C.M. 1946. The Late Bronze Age Razors of the British Isles, Proceedings of the Prehistoric Society (N.S. 12 (XII)).
A fragment of a medieval silver long cross penny of uncertain ruler, class or mint.
A cut silver quarter voided long cross penny of Henry III (1216-1272). Probably class 2-3 dating to 1248-1250, London mint.
A silver halfpenny of Henry VI, first reign (1422-1461), pinecone-mascle issue. Obverse legend reads [+] hENRIC pinecone REX ◊ ANGL. London mint. As North (1991), p77, number 1468.

A lead alloy disc, probably a token, 24.1mm in diameter and of late post medieval date. One side is stamped with faint lettering which appears to be retrograde and may read WB&T / P[...]/ S(I)[...] / 17(08?). The other side is blank. The 18th century date is unclear.

A group of three uniface post medieval lead alloy tokens from the same location with cross and pellet designs. All circa 17th-18th century. From top left to bottom right in the photo (measurements are diameter, thickness, weight): 1, incomplete (20.1mm by 3.3mm, 5.97g). 2, (16.6mm by 3.9mm, 4.38g). 3, (14.0mm by 2.6mm, 1.94g).

A group of seven post medieval uniface lead alloy tokens from the same location. All circa 17th-18th century. From top left to bottom right in the photo (measurements are diameter, thickness, weight): A stylised leaf or other form with six pairs of lines or chevrons radiating from a stalk (22.5mm by 4.4mm, 13.29g). Letters IM or WI (20.8mm by 1.8mm, 5.25g). Letter T (15.9mm by 1.9mm, 2.13g). Letter T (15.5mm by 2.9mm, 4.30g). Indeterminate form, possibly a bust facing left or a keyhole shape. Reverse may have a crude letter S (18.3mm by 2.0mm, 3.52g). Letter T with three pellets (16.5mm, 2.0mm, 2.40g). A damaged token with three pellets (20.1mm by 2.9mm, 4.30g).

A uniface lead alloy token, 25.5mm in diameter. One side has a prominent coat of arms with a chevron, a small lis between two unclear elements above and another unclear element below. Possibly the arms of the worshipful company of Tylers and Bricklayers. Circa 18th century.

A copper alloy medieval single loop D-shaped buckle with a narrowed and offset strap bar and a notched pin rest flanked by small transverse ridges. Complete with a copper alloy pin curled around the bar. Circa 13th - 14th century.
A silver medieval short cross penny of John (1199-1216), class 6b2 dating from 1208-1217. Moneyer probably Robert, Canterbury mint.

depictions.title:
The Battle of Hastings was fought in 1066, at this site around 5 miles from Hastings itself.

The battlefield is now within the grounds of Battle Abbey.  The information board is one of several around the battlefield site, telling the story of the battle.

descriptions.value: Battle Abbey is a partially ruined abbey complex in the small town of Battle in East Sussex, England. The abbey was built on the scene of the Battle of Hastings and dedicated to St. Martin.The name was initially the monastery of St (...)

Senlac Hill (or Senlac Ridge) is the location where Harold Godwinson deployed his army for the Battle of Hastings on 14 October 1066. The name Senlac was popularised by the Victorian historian E.A. Freeman based solely on a description of the battle by the Anglo-Norman chronicler Orderic Vitalis (...)

The Battle of Hastings reenactment is a yearly reenactment of the Battle of Hastings, held at Battle Abbey in Battle, East Sussex, UK, and drawing participants from around the world.BBC News: "Normans fight Saxons... and the rain" (...)

A complete Medieval silver penny of Edward I (AD 1272- 1307), dating to AD 1306-7. Probably Class 10cf2. London mint with Cross Moline initial mark. North (1991: 32) no. 1041.

A late Iron Age silver stater of the British Iron Age dating to c. 60 BC to 20 AD. A South Western uninscribed (Durotrigian) type. A stylised wreath on the obverse and a stylised horse on the reverse. The right-hand side of the reverse is largely off the flan and it is not possible to decide how parallel or convergent the three lines are. Reference: ABC Rudd's 'Cranborne Chase' type No. 2157 / No. 2160 Diameter: 19.06 mm Weight: 5.57 g Die Axis: 7

Three flint flakes and one chert flake: 1] A tertiary flake of dark grey Portland chert. Both ends have been broken off and there is some edge damage. There are waves of percussion visible on the ventral face and three parallel flaking scars on the dorsal face. Dimensions: Weight: 6 g 2] A secondary flake of pale grey and off white patchy flint with milky low-gloss patina.There is a small striking platform and bu;lb of percussion at the proximal end . The flaking scars on the dorsal face run at right angles to the direction this flake was removed in. Dimensions: Weight: 13 g 3] A tertiary flake of pale grey and off white patchy flint with a low-gloss patina. Both ends have been broken off and there is some edge damage. There are waves of percussion visible on the ventral face and two parallel flaking scars on the dorsal face. Dimensions: Weight: 6 g 4] A primary flake of grey brown flint with white mottles and a high-gloss patina. The proximal end has been broken off and there is some edge damage. There are waves of percussion visible on the ventral face and the remnant of the bulb of percussion. The dorsal face is covered in abraded nodule cortex.. Dimensions: Weight: 7 g Date: Neolithic to Early Bronze Age -

A sherd of white ware pottery. The fabric is pinkish-white at the core with cream-coloured margins. It is tempered with moderate fine sand and occasional redish pieces (possibly iron rich stone). A base sherd from a flagon. The base is flat with a slight bead on the body. Wheel made. Slightly abraded. Date: Roman - c. AD 50- 100 Weight: 38 g

A sherd of colour coated fineware. New Forest ware. The fabric is reduced blue-grey with a buff interior margin and brownish colour coat on the exterior. It is tempered with fine sand and highly fired. A body sherd. Wheel made. Slightly abraded. Date: Roman - c. AD 260 - 370 Weight: 9 g

Four sherds of Black Burnished Ware pottery. The fabrics are reduced dark to mid grey and tempered with abundant rounded quartz sand. Three pieces are of Poole/Wareham fabric and one is possible the South Western variant. There are traces of burnish on the exterior surfaces. One sherd from flat base, probably from a jar. Three undiagnostic body sherds. One sherd has scratch marks on both surfaces. Handmade. Abraded. Date: Roman - 1st to 4th Century Weight: 33 g

One sherd of glazed earthenware pottery. The fabric is reduced pale grey at the core and pinkish orange at the margins. It is tempered with abundant rounded quartz sand. There are traces of yellow-green lead glaze on the exterior surface. A body sherd from a jug. Handmade. Abraded. Date: Early Medieval - 13th to 14th century Weight: 5 g

One sherd of unglazed earthenware pottery. The fabric is reduced pale grey at the core and a dark grey at the margins. It is tempered with abundant rounded quartz sand and rare calcareous stone pieces (up to 3 mm). A rim sherd from a necked jar or jug. The rim is upright, has an external bead on the exterior edge and a grooved lid seat on the flat top. Handmade. Abraded. Date: Early Medieval - 12th to 14th century Weight: 100 g

One sherd of unglazed earthenware pottery. The fabric is reduced pale grey patchy buff oxidisation on the exterior margin. It is tempered with moderate rounded quartz sand and sparse calcareous stone pieses (up to 3 mm). A sherd from a near the everted rim of the vessel, which was probably a jar. Handmade. Abraded. Date: Early Medieval - 13th to 14th century Weight: 20 g

One sherd of unglazed earthenware pottery. The fabric has a reduced pale grey core with oxidised orange-buff margins and is tempered with moderate rounded quartz sand (up to 2 mm). A body sherd, probably from a jar. Handmade. Slightly abraded. Date: Early Medieval - 13th to 14th century Weight: 9 g

Four sherds of unglazed earthenware pottery. The fabrics have a reduced pale grey core with occasionally oxidised orange-buff margins. All are tempered abundant fie sand and occasional calcareous stone pieces (up to 3 mm). There is a single rim sherd from an everted rimmed jar, which has an external small bead on the outer edge, a wider, low bead on the upper edge and internal lid seat ridge. The remaining three are body sherds. The sherds are externally sooted and thin-walled. All are from hand made vessels, probably cooking jars. All are slightly abraded. Date: Early Medieval - 13th to 14th century Weight: 37 g

Seven sherds of unglazed earthenware pottery. The fabrics are patchily reduced and oxidised, varying from dark grey to pale pinkish-orange. All are tempered with a coarse and poorly sorted mix moderate calcareous stone pieces and occasional flint and rounded quartz sand. The temper pieces are up to 5 mm in size. There are two base sherds, both flat. There is a single rim sherd from a necked vessel, probably a jug. The rim is flat-topped with a slight external bead. The remaining four are undiagnostic body sherds. Some pieces are slightly externally sooted. All are from hand made vessels, probably jars and jugs. All are slightly abraded. Date: Early Medieval - 13th to 14th century Weight: 51 g

28 sherds of unglazed earthenware pottery. The fabrics are patchily reduced and oxidised, varying from dark grey, through pale grey and buff to orange red. All are tempered with a coarse and poorly sorted mix of abundant fine and rounded quartz sand together with moderate flint and calcareous stone pieces (including occasional fossil shell). The temper pieces are up to 5 mm in size. There are three base sherds, all flat. There are six rim sherds; three beaded, one flat-topped, one everted with and internal bead and one plain, rounded and cupped rim. The remaining 19 are undiagnostic body sherds. All are from hand made vessels, probably jars. All are abraded. Date: Early Medieval - 12th to 13th century Weight: 177 g

A fragment of a Roman base silver finger ring. All that remains is half of the bezel of the and one rounded shoulders. The bezel is oval in shape and has a recess to accommodate an intaglio. It tapers into a rounded shoulder. It tapers into a narrow band. The shoulder and band are D-shaped in cross section. The surface of the ring is smooth and worn. The surface colour is patchily grey and brown indicating base silver. Date: Roman - c. AD 100 - 400 Dimensions: 20.91 mm x 12.86 mm x.79 mm Weight: 3.38 g This ring is similar to database record LVPL-7691D4 where Teresa Gilmore notes that this style of finger ring is classified as a Guiraud type V, consistent with a 2nd to 3rd century date.

A complete, silver gilt iconographic finger ring. The bezel is divided longitudinally into two sub-rectangular facets, both transversely concave, meeting in a pointed ridge at the middle. Either facet is engraved with an incised depiction of an unidentified saint or martyr, both robed and nimbed. Either shoulder is decorated with a continuation of the central rib, incised with chevrons and flanked on each side by an incised double strand with a band of short incised diagonal lines at the outer edges. These elements are curved as they reach the rear of the hoop, each ending in a diagonal ridge flanking a worn and undecorated area. The rear of the hoop is D-shaped in cross section. The interior of the hoop is worn. The surfaces are gilded with some wear to the high points. Dimensions: 24.35 mm x 2.91 mm Weight: 6.57 g Date: Late Medieval to Post Medieval - c. 1400 - 1500 Discussion: A number of similar finger rings have been reported through the treasure process and are recorded on the PAS database, mostly dated to the 15th century. Cf. 2008T119, 2015T219, and CORN-632D6E, a pre-1997 find. This find is 300 years old and composed of more than 10% precious metal, and therefore should be considered Treasure under the terms of the Treasure Act 1996

An incomplete copper alloy penannular brooch, The frame has been stratched out of its original sub circular shape and the pin is missing. The frame is lozengiform in cros section and the front face is decorated with incised transverse grooves over the whole length, The tapered ends of the frame have been bent back on themselves to form the terminals. These have also been decorated with transverse incised grooves. Date: Late Roman to Early Medieval - c. AD 350 - 600 Dimensions: 49.88 mm x 25.37 mm x 2.03 mm Weight: 2.26 g
A penny of Edward I. Class 9b1 dating to 1299 - 1300/1. Bristol mint. Reference: North Vol II, no. 1037/1 Date: Medieval Diameter: 17.84 mm Weight: 1.34 g Die axis: 1

A copper alloy three-part cosmetic set. The comprises an ear scoop, tweezers and a nail cleaner. All three are pierced at the top with a circular hole through which thy are joined using a circular rivet with flared ends. The ear spoon has a rounded attachment end to accomodate the attachment hole. There is a slight transverse collar below, The sides are narrowed at the top before flaring out into the flat, round-ended scoop. Te edges of the sides are chamfered from the front. The rear of he scoop is flat. The tweezers are in two pieces with a break at the attachment end and both appear to be broken at the ends of the arms.The arms also have chamferefed side edges from the outer faces and are flat on the inner faces. the nail cleaner is of similar design to the ear scoop with a rounded attachment end, transverse collar, narroed sides with chamfered side edgs, The end has been broken but was originally bifurcated. One side of the bifurvcation has been broken off and the other bent out to the side. This has an expanded, rounded terminal. The rear is flat. The ear scoop and nail cleaner both have the ore finished faces facing outwards and flank the tweezers. Date: Roman Dimensions: 36.32 mm x 6.45 mm x 4.60 mm Weight: 3.67 g

A copper alloy double sided coin weight for the silver Unite of James I dating to 1604-1619. The weight is 145.7 grains which compares with the expected weight of the unite of 155 grains. Die one: [I R B]RIT - Half length figure of the king with orb and sceptre Side two: Crown above XII - 12 shillings value Reference: Withers, P & B R , 1995, Page 25 Date: Early Post Medieval - c. 1604 - 1619 Dimensions: 17.84 mm x 18.18 mm x 4.30 mm Weight: 9.44 g

depictions.title: This effigy in the porch greets visitors to Abbotsbury parish church and depicts one of the Abbots of the former abbey. It was placed in the church after it was unearthed during excavations. Other relics can be found in the churchyard in the form of medieval stone coffins.

descriptions.value: Abbotsbury is a village and civil parish in the English county of Dorset. It is in the West Dorset district and is situated about inland from the English Channel coast. In the 2011 census the civil parish had a population of 481 (...)

Abbotsbury Abbey, dedicated to Saint Peter, was a Benedictine monastery in the village of Abbotsbury in Dorset, England. The abbey was founded in the eleventh century by King Cnut's thegn Orc and his wife Tola, who handsomely endowed the monastery with lands in the area (...)

Portesham, sometimes also spelled Portisham, is a village and civil parish in the county of Dorset in southwest England, situated in the West Dorset administrative district approximately northwest of Weymouth, southwest of the county town Dorchester, and northeast of the Jurassic Coast World (...)

A complete cast copper-alloy double-ended harness link of early medieval to medieval date (c. AD 1000-1100.) Description: The object consists of a roughly D-shaped cross-sectioned bar, which has a plain plano-convex central boss. The arms of the bar terminate in circular loops within tripple-knobbed sub-rectangular frames. The object has a light green patina with some brown mottling. Measurements: length: 70.2mm; width (of terminals): 20.1mm; thickness (at central boss): 8.3mm; weight: 14.36g Discussion: According to Williams (2007, 1) these harness links are Anglo-Scandinavian in origin and derive from the Viking Ringerike style, as seen on examples where the boss is a distinct animal mask. They were used as horse accoutrements to join leather straps such as on cheek pieces, bits and harness links of the period. Williams suggests an 11th century date but indicates they may have had a longer life in England. Cf. Williams (Ibid), p. 3.

A fragment of a gilt silver finger ring of medieval date (c.1300-1500). Description: The fragment represents the quatrefoil bezel of the ring and part of the hoop to which the bezel is soldered on the underside. The bezel has at its centre a four branches or leaves, probably palm leaves symbolising the four gospels which tell of Jesus’ entry into Jerusalem. These are represented by engraved recesses creating the spaces between the leaves of the palms. Each quadrant of the bezel is impressed with a different motif which clockwise are as follows: an 'I'; '[h]'; 'C'; and finally, a flared-arm cross. The Christogram initials IhC are in lombardic lettering and denote the first three letters of the Greek name of Jesus. The cast symbols in relief create impressed circular surrounding fields, in turn creating a raised border around the edge of the bezel as well as between each quadrant. Measurements: length: 13.4mm; width: 11.9mm; thickness: 2.67mm; weight: 1.44g Discussion: Finger rings with similar applied quatrefoil bezels have been reported through the treasure act and recorded onto the PAS database. Those with simple bezels (LANCUM-254BF6 and LANCUM-0E7C1A) are dated 14th century and 14th-15th century respectively, while NMS-093C14 has been more broadly dated to c.1450-1700. WMID-D4CD51 and SOM-F8FE47, whose bezels both feature foliate designs, are dated 13th-15th century and 14th century respectively while SUR-D2DFEA, which has a moulded face at the centre of the bezel, is dated late 14th to 17th century. A more decorative ring, with stone-set shoulders and ruby set in the centre of a quatrefoil bezel engraved with palm leaves which is dated 14th century can be seen in Oman (1993, P. 11, No. 261). The phrase “Ihc nazarenus rex iudeorum” was inscribed above the head of Jesus on the cross during his crucifixion. It is a phrase which was commonly employed on medieval objects, primarily, finger rings and brooches, for their perceived magical qualities in curing or averting illness and misfortune. The IhC Jesus invocation cult gained popularity in the mid 14th century before becoming embroiled in the religious turmoil of the 16th and 17th centuries, some seeing the practise as popish with catholic connotations. A date range of c.1300- 1500 is therefore suggested for the example recorded here. Conclusion: It is therefore clear that this object likely dates to before 1721 and as the object is made of more than 10% precious metals, it constitutes potential Treasure under the stipulations of The Treasure Act 1996.

A heavily worn and warped silver Medieval halfpenny of Edward III (1327-1377) probably Second (star marked) Coinage, 1335-1343. London Mint. Measurements: 15.05mm in diameter, 0.49mm thick and 0.45g in weight.

A slightly worn and clipped silver sixpence of Charles I (1625-1649). Minted between 1636 and 1638 at the Tower of London, tun mint mark, North (1991) No. 2241. Measurements: 26.67mm in diameter, 0.86mm thick and 3g in weight.

A slightly worn silver post-Medieval sixpence of Elizabeth I (1558-1603), dated 1583, (North's) third issue of coinage (1583-1603), Mint mark: Bell. North (1991) no. 2015. Measurements: 25.33mm in diameter, 0.97mm thick and 2.66g in weight.

A Post-Medieval copper-alloy Rose Farthing (of Type 2) of Charles I (1625-1649) dating to the period 1636-1644. Mintmark: Crescent. North (1991) no.2291. Measurements: 13.21mm in diameter, 1.33mm thick and 0.97g in weight

A silver cufflink utilising a milled colonial one half real of Philip V of Spain (second reign, 1724 - 1746) dated 1742, minted at Mexico City, Assayer Mark "M" Manuel de la Pena. Calico (1982, 256) type 200. Description: The coin has been doubly pierced at the centre with two rivets with hammered heads through from the reverse. These would have attached to an incomplete loop. The coin is a milled half real of the Mexico city mint. Obverse: Crowned arms of Spain in round/oval shield, small rosette either side of the shield. Legend: "+PHS V.D.G.HISP.ET.IND.R.". Reverse: Crowned globes flanked by crowned and bannered pillars, legend from 8 o'clock Legend: VTRA.QUE.VNUM / Mo.1742.M." Measurements: 15.5mm diameter, 1.93mm thick (including rivets, 1.02mm without) and 1.59g in weight Discussion: Coins utilised as cufflinks are a not unknown occurrence with the first recorded on the PAS utilising coins of Elizabeth I (NARC-132E07), with the most recent being 19th century Ruppee (SWYOR-2CAAE3).

A fragment of cast probable hand bell or small hanging bell of probable 17th-19th century date. Description: The fragment is small and triangular and represents the lower section of the body, part of the belt and the lip. The outer face is convex and the internal is concave. Full diameter was roughly 70mm. The belt of the bell, dividing the body from the lip is slightly cast in relief with some finishing via incising or bevelling. The bell fragment is a dark grey colour. Measurements: 43.5mm wide, 42.67mm high, 7.13mm thick and 21.24g in weight

A fragment of copper-alloy vessel, likely dating between c.AD 1400- 1800. Description: The fragment represents part of the rim of a cauldron, skillet or similar vessel with the rim formed by a thickened section at the top of a thin wall. It is roughly triangular in plan. The outer surface is rough possibly unfinished or shows the vessel was heated with the lead leaching out of the surface. The internal surface is however noticeably smoother. The entire fragment is heavily patinated dark green and the breaks rough. Measurements:56.87mm long, 42.03mm high, 5.06mm thick and 34.81g in weight

An incomplete Neolithic flint leaf arrowhead (4000 BC-2350 BC). A incomplete broad leaf-shaped arrowhead formed from a thin flake. The tip is lost but what remains suggests that the object was of elongated ogival form when complete. Both sides are invasively worked and retouch around the edges of both sides are short, low angled and parallel. This arrowhead is grey and semi-translucent. It is unclear whether the tip of the arrowhead was lost in antiquity or recently. Length: 33.3mm; width: 19.2mm; thickness: 3.2mm. Weight: 2.09g.

Silver halfcrown of William III (1694-1702). Draped first bust facing right with B (Bristol mint) below shoulder. Type 2 reverse, four crowned cruciform large shields concave at the top. Harp has top left well above top right. All around central lion of Nassau. Date 1696 on reverse. OCTAVO around edge. Spink 3482

A medieval copper alloy mount. The head shows a knight wearing a round helmet over a chain mail hood which covers both cheeks. The back is completely flat; there is a deep hole in the rear that could have been used as a fixing point. There are small remains of a red pigment on the front and it appears that it has been broken off at the base. The mount is 35mm in length, 23.5mm in width and 14mm in depth. It weighs 41.8g

A copper alloy rowel from a spur of Medieval to Post-Medieval date. The rowel is in the form of a seven pointed star, with a central perforation for attachment to the spur. The rowel has a dark green, even patina and is worn. It has a diameter of 28.8mm, is 3.1mm thick, with the central perforation having a diameter of 2.8mm. The rowel weighs 4.8g.

A complete pair of Post-Medieval copper alloy nut crackers likely dating to the later 18th century. The nut crackers consist of two identical arms hinged together at the top. The hinge is held by a copper alloy axis bar. The upper part of each arm is made up of two solid plates, each with three facets, trapezoidal in cross-section. The inside surface of each has five rows of three triangular nicks designed to hold the nut securely while the outside surface, is decorated with stamped decoration consisting of random clusters of annulets. Below this section the arms are moulded with a series of transverse grooves. The final part of each arm, the 'handles', are D-shaped in cross-section and curve initially away from the main area and then taper back in, before terminating with flared-out points. When the handles are closed, there is an oval space created between the two handles. The nut crackers measures 105.7 mm in length, 29.0 mm wide, 17.2 mm thick and weighs 58.19 g. Several other complete or nearly complete nut crackers have been recorded on the PAS database including: HESH-C61FB3, WMID-1BA804, LVPL-EDF472, LEIC-E45056, YORYM-606167, SWYOR-EE9E14, LVPL-314DB0 and HAMP3159. All are considered to be late 18th Century in date.

A complete cast copper alloy object, possibly a handle of Post Medieval date. The main part of the object is made up of two part-spheres joined with a circumferential raised rib at the junction. On one side of this there is an extended spherical knop. On the other there is a cylindrical concave shaped collar which steps down to a lozengiform tang. The tang curves to one side in a regular way suggesting that the curvature is not the result of damage. The most likely suggestion is that this object is a furniture handle. The dimensions are as follows - Overall length: 74.54 mm; large knob diam. 27.84; top finial knob diam. 9.83; collar ring diam. 14.60; max. shaft thickness 2.86; min. shaft thickness 2.86. Weight: 72.78 g.
Roman coin: an as or dupondius of an unknown Emperor, mint and reverse. It probably dates to the mid to late 2nd century when considering the hair style of the bust.

A cast copper double looped oval shaped buckle. The loops are decorated on the exterior edge with an integral knop at the apex of each loop which appears to be in the form of an acorn. On the interior edge of each apex there is a shallow convex protrusion. There is also a acorn shape at each tertminal of the strap bar. The strap bar is slightly narrowed, and is triangular in section. The reverse is undecorated and is hollow beneath the knops. In plan the buckle is almost flat, but is broken recently ito two. The pin is an incomplete sub elongated triangle which is curled around the strap bar. The buckle loops have traces of a dark green patina, but is generally heavily abraded. The buckle measures 67.12mm long and 53.84mm wide. It weighs 14.11g. Whitehead (1996 Buckles 1250-1800 Greenlight Publishing) illustrates a similar shaped buckle, No. 371 which is dated to the mid 16th to mid 17th centuries. The recorded example is considerably larger than the published example.

An Early Bronze Age copper-alloy developed flat axe, Arreton industrial phase, c.1700-1500BC. The blade is wide, but appears to have beren worn down unevenly, meaning that both tips are at a sharp angle. There is no sign of an edge bevel remaining. There are no side nicks at the junction of the haft end with the blade. Very low flanges (c.1mm high). There are convex sides with no casting flashes The butt of the axe appears to be damaged as it is uneven and worn. There is a similar, although larger, example in Rohl and Needham page 127, number 89. Length 51.1mm, width across cutting edge 24.1mm, width at butt end 16.4mm, weight 40.8g.
Copper alloy strip, flat cross-section with beaded decoration down each edge.
Copper alloy book clasp.

depictions.title:
Pevsner describes Bayham Old Abbey as "The most impressive monastic ruin of Sussex". Bayham belonged to the Premonstratensian Order, founded at Otham in Kent about 1200 direct from Premontre and moved to Bayham between 1208 and 1211. The church and the buildings around the cloister are surprisingly high. This view looks from the high altar where a tree has enveloped the wall beyond.

See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayham_Old_Abbey for more information.

Small fragment of a medieval (14th or 15th century) decorated floor tile. The fragment is broadly sub-rectangular consisting of only one lower part of a much large square or rectangular tile. The fabric of the tile is relatively hard with a number of angular and sub-angular quartz (both abundant rose and infrequent white) iron stone and grit inclusions. The fabric is also mica rich. The fabric colour is a uniform mid orange brown. The fabric has a series of crack like voinds where the clay forming it has been folded and worked. The upper surface of the tile has been decorated with a pattern due to the size it is difficult to understand what the overall pattern was. It is possible that this was part of a larger design comprising four tile tessellating block as the linking design; alternatively it may be a decorated runner / half tile from the border of a larger pavement. What remains of the design consists of three horizontal blobs of yellow pipe clay; with the eye of faith the rear and foot of a lion passant can be seen, likewise these gould be elements of a crude vegetal scroll. All of these designs have been formed by impressing the surface of the tile with a die to create the pattern. The pattern is then filled with a white (usually pipe) clay wash that fills the stamped design. This has been further augmented by the application of a yellow coloured glaze / wash to the entire is upper surface. When fired this has produced a two tone yellow / brown red pattern present on this tile. Much of this surface has decayed and been lost and the pipe clay has deteriorated slightly and is now a mid buff / pale yellow colour. Only one part of the original edge of teh tile survives - all others are broken. There is no evidence of mortar on any of the surfaces of the tile. This suggests that they were laid either on a bed of sand or straight onto a leveled beaten earth floor. The upper surface with the design impressed upon it is smoother than the other faces and this might be a direct result of in situ wear. This style of two tone decorative floor tile is relatively common in both churches and high status secular buildings dating from the later medieval period 1300-1450. Comparative studies with other medieval tiles from Much Wenlock and across teh county have been undertaken and a similar example of this design has not been found. The tile measures 72.0mm length, 84.4mm width, is 26.1mm thick and weighs 198 grams.

A cast copper alloy axe or knife blank / ingot of Chalcolithic / Early Bronze Age date (2450 - 2300 BC). The blank is oval in shape with the butt being rounded narrowed and tapered. In profile it is lentoid in shape and its cross section is a similar lentoid shape. The 'cutting' edge is rounded, from the external edges it tapers gradually until it forms a narrowed but rounded but. There is no sign of a stop ridge or any form of cast design. It is thickest at the mid-point. The surface of the blank is heavily eroded and corroded, small areas of original patinated surface survive but on the whole the surface is pitted and corroded with an eroded surface. It is a dark - mid green colour. The metallic composition of the knife has been analysed by Dr Eleanor Blakelock, Birmingham Museums Trust. Her report is produced below: X-ray florescence analysis was undertaken on the surface of the objects using a Bruker M1 Mistral desktop XRF in the Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery conservation laboratory. The results suggests that the axe blank is a copper rich alloy with trace elements of arsenic, antinomy, lead and silver. This composition is typical for an Early Bronze Age date. The analysis however was carried out on the surface of the corroded object therefore the results may not be entirely representative of the core alloy of the dagger/knife. The form of this blank is similar to a number that Dr Stuart Needham has highlighted in his work on the Early Bronze Age metalwork from the Welsh Marches. Dr Needham was kind enough to examine this artefact and confirmed that he felt it was an unfinished or unworked blank because a) the profiles were unsymmetrical and b) the unrefined shape in plan being sub-trapezoidal or oval in shape c) the xrf results indicate an alloy of early composition. The axe-blank measures 77.6mm in length, 35.9mm width, and is 5.5mm thick. It weighs 59.87 grams.
A Roman nummus of the House of Constantine Reverse type: Two standards between two soldiers (330-340) Reece Period: 17

A very heavily worn silver halfgroat of Elizabeth I (1558-1603) the obverse and reverse are heavily polished - under raking light and magnification the remains of a long cross fourchee over a royal shield can be seen.
A complete silver penny of Edward I (AD 1272 - 1307) possibly dating to c. AD 1280 - 1291. Mint of Canterbury. Possibly class 3 - 5, North 1016 - 1029.

An incomplete copper alloy Polden Hill brooch of Roman date, circa (AD80-120). The lower part of the bow, foot of the brooch, catch plate, rearward facing hook, pin, spring, axis bar and both wing caps are all missing. The remains of the brooch consist of the head and upper part of the bow. The bow head is hump-like, and slightly angular (comma shaped) in profile. The bow is broad and tapers to a damaged rounded terminal, with a well-developed patina. At the rear of the head of the brooch is a recess that would have held the coiled spring and pin which are both now missing. A ridge is present at the shoulder between the wings and the bow. There is a central incised groove running the length of the remains of the bow. The object has a green to mid brown coloured even patina. Abrasion, caused by movement whilst within the plough soil, has resulted in the loss of some of the original surface detail. There are many similar examples on the database that have been found across the West Midlands, one example was discovered in Bidford on Avon, Warwickshire (WAW-E3B44C) and (WMID-B4FBF5) discovered in Birmingham. Bayley and Butcher (2004:160) comment that the distribution of Polden Hill brooches is concentrated in the West Midlands. Similar brooches are illustrated by Bayley and Butcher (2004:p.88-89). The brooch measures 22.8mm in length, 14.76mm width (across damaged wings), 8.9mm thick at the head and the brooch weighs 4.4 grams. Bayley, J. and Butcher, S., (2004) Roman Brooches in Britain: A technological and Typological Study Based on the Richborough Collection.London, Society of Antiquaries.

A copper-alloy medieval Nuremberg "Ship penny" jetton dating to the period AD 1490-1550. Obverse type depicting a ship, with stern flag on the right and bow pennant on the left. Fictitious legend. Reverse type depicting four fleurs de lis in a lozenge. Fictitious legend. A similar example is illustrated in Mitchiner M. (1988), p. 371, no. 1162.

A complete struck / hammered copper alloy square trader's halfpenny token, issued by Thomas Dedicot of Bewdley, Worcestershire between 1661 and 1667AD. Williamson no 7, p 1260. Obverse: THOMAS / DEDICOT / GROCER / HIS HALF / PENNY Reverse: IN / BEWDLEY / (Three Cloves) / SQUARE / DEALING Length: 17.52mm Width: 17.07mm Thickness: 1.0mm Weight: 1.8 grams. According to Wiliamson, Thomas Dedicot was bailiff in Bewdley in 1661. In 1667 a William Dedicot succeeded Edward Longmore (who died in his office) and was bailiff again in 1680. Several other trade tokens issued by Thomas Dedicot have been recorded on thePAS database, including:WMID-36E7F6; HESH-2867CA; WMID-F54F36; WAW-A80664; SUR-C2F997; WMID3589 and WMID-002AB3.

"A gold amulet case - a simple cylindrical tube with three suspension loops. Dimensions and metal content: Length: 25mm; diameter: 6mm, height (tube plus loops): 11mm; weight: 4.38g. X-ray fluorescence analysis conducted at the British Museum indicated an approximate gold content of 99 per cent". - C.M. Johns. Quoted in the DCMS 2000 Treasure Report

A copper alloy unidentified object of possible Roman date. The object is irregular in plan and may be in the form of an animal such as a dolphin or a dragon. The object has a curved and pointed 'head' from the top of which is a triangular projection. Behind the 'head' is a circular hole measuring 4mm in diameter for attachment. The object has a triangular arch at the back and curves round where it terminates in a possible tail. The 'tail' is encrusted with a brown corrosion, probably iron, and what appears to be the remains of an iron rivet attached. The surface of the object is undulating and corroded with no remaining patina. The condition of the object has made it difficult to date or be certain of the exact function. A Roman dolphin drop handle is a possibility. Dimensions: 50mm in length, 23mm in width, 6mm thick, 24.5g
A silver sixpence of James I, (1603-1625). Reverse: QVAE DEVS CONIVNXIT NEMO SEPARET; square shield with 1623 above. Third coinage, sixth bust. IM: thistle. North no. 2126.

A lead alloy musket ball dating from the Post-Medieval period, (1500-1800). The object is spherical and weighs 9.8g. At one end of the object the spru remains attached. The musket ball is light cream in colour and is damaged at one end possibly due to the plough.

A lead alloy musket ball dating from the Post-Medieval period, (1500-1800). The object is spherical and weighs 9.5g. The remains of a casting seem and spru can be seen. The musket ball is light cream in colour and is damaged at one end possibly due to the plough.

A large lead alloy musket ball dating from the Post-Medieval period, (1500-1800). The object is spherical and weighs 23.3g. A high casting seem is visible around the object as are striations. A concave spru remains attached to the casting seem. The musket ball is light grey in colour and is damaged at one end possibly due to the plough.

A large lead alloy musket ball dating from the Post-Medieval period, (1500-1800). The object is spherical and weighs 23.3g. A high casting seem is visible around the object as are striations. A concave spru remains attached to the casting seem. The musket ball is dark cream in colour.

A cast post-medieval silver buckle, probably dating from the 18th century. The buckle is asymmetrical and 'double looped', although only one loop of the frame is rounded; the back frame is roughly rectangular in plan and is separated from the rounded loop by the integrally cast narrowed pin bar. The buckle possess a pin that has been formed from a long tapered piece of silver that has been folded around the pin bar. The pin is rounded on the front face and flat on the rear face with a rounded tapered point. The pin rests on a flat piece of silver that has been wrapped around the outer edge of the rectangular frame. In profile this pin rest is cylindrical and has a visible seam along the vertical long edge. The front face of the buckle is decorated with a non-symmetrical design of floral and possible fruit and wildlife scenes. The buckle is in excellent condition, with virtually no wear. There do not appear to be any visible hallmarks or makers mark on the buckle which could suggest dates from circa AD 1740 to c1790, as during this period silver buckles weighing under ten pennyweights (approximately 14.6g) did not need to be hallmarked. The buckle measures in length 36.65mm, width 38.52mm, thickness 3.22mm, and weight 10.98g.

A complete post-medieval silver sixpence of Elizabeth I (1558-1603). The reverse shows the date of "1564", dating it to the third issue (1561-77). The entire outer rim (which would have contained the legend) has been clipped, making the coin the size of a half-groat. The clipping suggests this coin may have been in circulation until the mid-1650's. Both sides of the coin are extremely worn (especially the obverse) which coupled with the lack of inscriptions makes exact identification difficult. North 2015 (page 137), Spink 2561 (page 240). The coin has a 17.14mm diameter, is 0.63mm thick and weighs 0.93g.

A Post-Medieval silver halfgroat of James I, (AD 1603-1625) dating to AD 1605-6. Second coinage. Initial mark: Rose. Mint: London. North 1991, Vol.2 pg. 146 no.2104. The coin has a diameter of 17.46mm, a thickness of 0.63mm, and weighs 0.84g.

An unknown lead or lead alloy artefact, of uncertain dating and function. The artefact comprises two separate elements: a lead weight / sleeve and three thin joining fragments. The lead weight / sleeve is a pointed oval in shape, with a sub circular hole / perforation at the top and bottom. The lead weight / sleeve has been made from two separate pieces - a front and back, which have been secured together along the sides by being folded / pressed together. A gap is present between the two plates. The front plate is sub triangular in shape, and the back plate is a pointed oval. The front plate just has a hole at the bottom whereas the back plate has a hole at both the top and bottom. The top hole measures 4.1 mm in length, and 2.7 mm wide. The bottom hole measures 2.8 mm in length and 1.8 mm wide. The three thin fragments join together to form a sub circular shape. Vertical ridged decoration is present on all three pieces. The original form is uncertain. The lead weight / sleeve measures 31.8 mm in length, 22.1 mm wide and 8.1 mm thick. It weighs 18.5 g. The three fragments (from the left) measure: 18.4 mm in length, 7.4 mm wide, 2.1 mm thick and weigh 1.3 g; 21.3 mm in length, 8.2 mm wide, 2.5mm thick and weigh 1.7 g; 14.2 mm in length; 7.7 mm wide, 2.0 mm thick and weigh 0.5 g. All three fragments weigh 3.4 g. All together, the lead weight / sleeve and the three thin fragments weigh 21.7 g. All fragments are a mid to light grey colour, with an even surface patina. Abrasion, caused by movement whilst within the plough soil, has resulted in a loss of some of the original surface detail. No direct parallel to these objects has been found at the time of recording. Function and dating remain uncertain.

A cast lead alloy - possibly pewter - token of post medieval date. The token is well cast but incomplete having lost some of its edges through abrasion. The design on the front face consists of a vertical cross contained within an irregular shaped circlet encircled by a ring of pellets. The cross is formed from four wedges and in the angles are V shaped marks. The reverse face has a cast initial T with terminal serifs possibly another letter above and a small annulet to one side of the vertical element of the T. The overall style is similar to that of provincial mercantile tokens combining Powell's class 2 (initials) and Class 14 (crosses). The token measures 20.2mm length, 20.9mm width, is 3.7mm thick and weighs 3.66 grams

Buildwas Abbey was founded in 1135 when Roger de Clinton, Bishop of Chester, brought a small colony of monks from the Norman abbey of Savigny. They settled here at Buildwas on the banks of the River Severn.

*Source: English Heritage

descriptions.value: Buildwas Abbey is located along the banks of the River Severn in Buildwas, Shropshire, England, about two miles west of Ironbridge.  (...)

Buildwas is a village and civil parish in Shropshire, England, on the north bank of the River Severn at . It lies on the B4380 road to Atcham. The Royal Mail postcodes begin TF6 and TF8. Buildwas Primary School is situated on the Buildwas bank road (...)

Broseley is a small town in Shropshire, England, with a population of 4,912 (2001 census), increasing to 4,929 at the 2011 Census. The River Severn flows to the north and east of the town. An incomplete copper-alloy post-medieval pocket sundial. It is ring-shaped, 11.11mm wide, with a narrow slot along the centre of one side. Two grooves run parallel to this slot on either side of the outer face, while one groove runs around the centre of the inner face. Capital letters for each month of the year are arranged to either side of the slot on the outer face, while the numbers 1 to 12 are arranged on the opposite side of the inner face. A small copper-alloy wire loop remains in situ through two small holes to one end of the slot.   These sundials are known as simple ring dials or poke dials ('poke' being an archaic word for pocket). A separate sliding section would have been placed over the slot, allowing it to be moved according to the months of the year. Then, when positioned vertically, the sun would have shined through a small hole, illuminating the appropriate number on the opposite side of the interior. Turner (1980, 25) states 'a cheap dial, it was popular during the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries among country people who kept it in their poke, or pocket. Not infrequently they are literally unearthed'. Diameter: 38.12mm, width: 11.11mm, thickness: 1.87mm, weight: 14.49g

A complete Medieval copper-alloy finger ring dating to circa AD 1150-1450. It consists of the hoop, bezel and intact setting. The bezel is stirrup-shaped, sub-triangular in plan. Its face is convex whilst its underside is flat. Its face is undecorated. The setting on top of the bezel is a purple coloured glass cabochon. Stirrup-shaped finger rings with imitation gemstone settings were common from between 1AD150-1450. The ring closely resembles no. 1609 in Egan and Pritchard (1991). Length: 24.3mm; External diameter: 19.76mm; Height of bezel: 5.09mm; Hoop thickness: 1.41mm; Weight: 1.36g.
An incomplete (cut half) medieval penny of John, dating to the period AD 1200-1204. Class 4b or 4c. Minted in Canterbury or York by Hue. North vol.I, no.968/2 or 968/3

A complete copper alloy Roman dupondius of Antoninus Pius, dating to the period AD 138-161 (Reece period 7). Reverse probably featuring Libertas standing right, holding pileus and extending right hand. Mint of Rome.

A complete copper alloy Roman nummus of the House of Constantine, dating to the period AD 330-35 (Reece period 17). GLORIA EXERCITVS reverse type, depicting two soldiers with two standards between them. Uncertain mint.

A complete copper alloy Roman nummus of Valens, dating to the period AD 364-78 (Reece period 19). GLORIA ROMANORVM reverse type, depicting the emperor advancing right, dragging a captive. Uncertain mint.

A complete copper alloy Roman nummus of the House of Valentinian, dating to the period AD 364-78 (Reece period 19). SECVRITAS REI PVBLICAE reverse type, depicting Victory advancing left. Uncertain mint.

A complete copper alloy Roman contemporary copy of a nummus of the House of Constantine, dating to the period AD 355-61 (Reece period 18). Copying FEL TEMP REPARATIO reverse type, depicting a soldier spearing a fallen horseman.

A copper-alloy Medieval mount, dating to AD 1250-1350. It consists of a lozenge-shaped plate, which has an oval perforation at two opposite corners. Each of the side of the plate has a protruding half rounded knop. The front face of the plate has a raised edge and a raised central decoration depicting a central flower, which stands on the longitudinal axis of the plate dividing the field in two halves. Both halves have a further flower, which is connected to the central one through the base; the field of one half of the plate is inlaid with blue enamel while the other has purple inlay. The back face of the mount is flat and undecorated. Only for the shape see IOW-C49762. A close parallel has not been found. Length: 19.48mm Width: 15.37mm Thickness: 2.94mm Weight: 3.09g

A copper-alloy fragment of a Roman bracelet wth Snake's head terminal, dating to AD 43-410. It consists of a sub-rectangular strip of metal, which is sub rectangular in cross-section tapers towards a blunt point at one end, while the opposite end has a transverse break. The front face of the tapered terminal depicts a cast snake head. The fragment curved slightly in profile. The back face is undecorated. Cf SUR-FA2A8C, LEIC-582FB7, SF-146FD9, LEIC-50B499. Length: 23.42mm Width: 7.70mm Thickness of the strip: 1.43mm Thickness of the snake head terminal: 2.06mm Weight: 1.45g

An incomplete copper-alloy Medieval composite strap end, dating to AD 1300-1450. It consists of two rectangular outer plates and a central spacer, which now survives only in the lower part of the strap end. The attachment end of the plates is heavily damaged; originally both must have had two perforations at the upper corners but, today only one plate has a complete perforation with a copper alloy rivet and an incomplete second perforation.The lower edge of the plates and spacer have remainders of a central protruding point; just above the latter point there is a copper-alloy rivet securing the spacer to the plates. Although the surfaces are heavily damaged, both faces bear traces of silvering. Cf Egan-Pritchard (1991, p. 142, fig. 93, nos. 662, 653) Length: 33.86mm Width: 19.93mm Thickness: 2.94mm Weight: 4.76g

A lead Post Medieval weight to AD 1500-1800. It is a parallelepiped with nine annulets stamped on both of the wider faces. No parallels found. Length: 13.90mm Width: 13.62mm Thickness: 4.89mm Weight: 8.69g

A lead probably modern seal dating to AD 1800-1900. It consists of two discs folded over and connected by a strip. The outer face of one disc has an unclear design; the second disc is fragmentary and bears a series of letters on its outer face, possibly [...]VA[...]; it is not clear if a design accompany the letters. Diameter: 16.57mm Thickness: 2.91mm Weight: 2.08g

A lead probably Post Medieval unidentified object, dating to AD 1500-1800. It is a square plate which bear a cast decoration on either face; one face depicts probably an eagle; the other face has the following text arranged in three lines: (D)A(T)E/DABI/TUR pellet. The plate is slightly bent. No parallels found. The inscription is a short version of the Latin "date and dabitur vobis" which stands for "give, and it will be given to you". The expression is said by Jesus according to the Gospel of St Luke (6:38). The eagle is the traditionally associated with John the evangelist. Length: 19.52mm Width: 19.26mm Thickness: 2.02mm Weight: 7.07g
A lead Medieval to Post Medieval penny size "Boy Bishop" token, dating to AD 1470-1539. Obv: Mitre and crosier; [...] Rev: Long solid cross; three pellets in angles; [...] Cf Rigold (1978).

An incomplete copper alloy Medieval harness mount, dating to AD 1300-1450. It consists of a pointed oval plate which is slightly concave on its back face and has a circular perforation at either ends. The lower end has two integral prongs with a gap between them; the prongs consists of two rectangular cross-sectioned strips which are folded backwards on themselves to create two loops but, only one of theme survives now. The front face of the plate has an incised zigzag line running around the edges and continuing at the centre of the field with a C-shaped line. The front face of the prongs bears traces of gilding and are slightly bent. Length: 37.41mm Width: 16.42mm Thickness: 1.46mm Weight: 4.15g

A copper-alloy fragment of a Medieval to Post Medieval unidentified object, dating to AD 1250-1800. It is sub-triangular in plan and slightly arched in profile. The wider end is thicker and rectangular in cross-section; the opposite end is broken. The surfaces are worn. The fragment is similar to the unidentified SF-5115E4. Length: 13.55mm Width at the wider end: 19.84mm Thickness at the wider end: 5.25mm Weight: 3.81g

An incomplete copper-alloy Medieval French jetton, dating to AD 1350-1450. Obverse: Shield of France with three fleurs de lis inscribed in a beaded circle; +AVE [...] Reverse: double stranded arcuate cross fleury, fleur-de-lis at the centre, four saltire motifs in the field; +AVE[...] Cf LIN-5B8C23.

A copper-alloy Post Medieval "Rose/Orbe" German jetton probably of Iorg Shultes, dating to AD 1515-1559. Minted in Nuremberg. The jetton is slightly bent. Obv: Rosette surrounded by three crowns alternated with three fleur-de-lis; [...] SCHVL[...] Obv: Imperial orb surmounted by a cross patty, within a tressure with three main arches, pair of pellets in outer angles; [...] Cf Mitchiner (1988, p. 395).

A copper-alloy late Medieval French jetton, dating to AD 1450-1500. Obverse: beaded lozenge enclosing four fleur-de-les, within a four-arch tressure with trefoil in outer cusps; +VIVE lis LE sun ROI [...]VIVE [...]LE trefoil ROI. Reverse: short solid cross with plant motifs at the end of the arms and around; +GETTES pellet RICH pellet PAIES pellet RICH trefoil.
